Top-ranked Wildcats blast N. Carolina 84-70

Kentucky ran out to early lead and never looked back against No. 21 Tar Heels

UK 84, North Carolina 70: What we learned
Sullivan | Poythress injury a challenge for UK
UK's Alex Poythress tears ACL, season over

Top-ranked Wildcats blast N. Carolina 84-70

Kyle Tucker, ktucker@courier-journal.com 4:04 p.m. EST December 13, 2014

Kentuckys Karl-Anthony Towns rips down a rebound in the first half against North Carolina. December 13, 2014.(Photo: Matt Stone/The C-J)

27 CONNECT 11 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. University of Kentucky basketball players warmed up for their game against North Carolina on Saturday wearing T-shirts that read "Roar for 22" in honor of teammate Alex Poythress, who suffered a season-ending knee injury Thursday.

His jersey number is 22 and his motto is "Courage doesn't always roar." But Rupp Arena did when Poythress followed the team out of the tunnel on crutches and louder still as top-ranked Kentucky jumped on the 21st-ranked Tar Heels early and ran away with an 84-70 victory in the Cats' first game without their starting small forward.

Junior center Willie Cauley-Stein, Poythress' best friend and former roommate, played inspired from the opening tip. He produced nine points, three rebounds, two steals and an assist in his first eight minutes on the court as Kentucky (11-0) raced out to a 19-8 lead.

UK 84, NORTH CAROLINA: 70: What we learned

GAME REWIND: Look back at Wildcats' win over the Tar Heels

When the Tar Heels (6-3) cut the deficit to four with 7:39 left in the first half, Cauley-Stein erupted. He had an offensive rebound, swished hook shot, steal and two free throws in fewer than 30 seconds to give the Cats room to breathe and Poythress, seated courtside, a reason to clap.

Cauley-Stein finished with 15 points, six rebounds, four steals, two blocks and an assist.

Shooting guards Devin Booker and Aaron Harrison put even more distance between UK and UNC, swishing six 3-pointers and scoring 29 points between them Saturday. Harrison, who was shooting 22.7 percent from beyond the arc this season and had made just 3 of 16 in the previous four games, buried three in two minutes to close the first half.

The Wildcats led 49-34 at the half, having shot 55.6 percent overall and 6 of 12 from 3-point range. Kentucky entered the day ranked 305th nationally in 3-point percentage.


COURIER-JOURNAL

Alex Poythress honored by Kentucky basketball players with #RoarFor22 shirts


Even when North Carolina's Marcus Paige heated up, hitting four threes in the second half, the Cats kept bombing away. Booker's 3-pointer with 14:40 to go in the game pushed UK's lead to 19. The Heels were never closer than nine for the final 23 minutes.

When they got within a dozen with five minutes to go, Cauley-Stein did his thing again. In the span of a minute, he threw down soaring slams, dived for a steal and called timeout while sprawled on the floor. The lead was 18 again in a blink.

UK Coach John Calipari talks about 84-70 win over North Carolina. Matt Stone, The C-J

Poythress' replacement in the starting lineup, freshman Trey Lyles, had nine points, three rebounds, a steal and an assist in 23 minutes. Coach John Calipari still used platoons at times, although he used only nine players and thus mixing and matching the fifth guy in a given group. Other times he used complete jumbled groupings.

Freshman point guard Tyler Ulis, a second-platooner, shined with an increase workload: eight assists, three turnovers in 24 minutes. Sophomore Marcus Lee also helped the Cats fill the void with eight points on 4-of-4 shooting. Seven Wildcats scored at least seven points.

And on a day meant to honor Poythress, everyone roared for 22.

Kyle Tucker can be reached at (502) 582-4361. Follow him on Twitter @KyleTucker_CJ.
